content: How can I help you today?

I've been having a hard time sleeping lately. My mind is constantly racing at night, thinking about work and whether I might lose my job. I'm stressed about providing for my family, especially with two young kids and bills piling up. My partner thought talking to someone might help, so here I am.

Thank you for sharing that. It sounds like you've been carrying a lot of stress and responsibility, and your concern for your family's well-being shows how deeply you care about them. It's understandable that all of this has been weighing on your mind and affecting your sleep. What would you like to focus on in this conversation today?

I guess I'd like to figure out how to stop these racing thoughts at night and manage this constant stress about work. It feels like no matter how much I try to relax, my brain just won't turn off, and it's exhausting.

It sounds like you're looking for ways to calm your mind and find some relief from the stress that's keeping you awake at night. The exhaustion you're feeling must be overwhelming, especially with so much on your plate. What have you tried so far to help yourself relax or manage these racing thoughts?

I’ve tried going to bed earlier, but it doesn’t help. Sometimes I’ll scroll through my phone to distract myself, but that just seems to make things worse. My partner suggested deep breathing or meditation, but I feel too restless to even sit still and do that. Honestly, I just end up lying there, thinking about all the worst-case scenarios.

It sounds like you've made efforts to find relief, but it hasn’t been easy, especially when your mind keeps fixating on those worries. It’s tough when even relaxing techniques feel out of reach in those moments. The worst-case scenarios can be so consuming, and scrolling through your phone may offer a distraction but doesn’t seem to provide the calm you're hoping for. What do you think might help you feel even a little more at ease during those restless nights?

Honestly, I’m not even sure what might help at this point. It feels like I’ve tried everything I can think of, but nothing really works. Maybe if I could figure out how to shut off those thoughts or feel more secure about work, it might make a difference. But right now, it all just feels so overwhelming.

It sounds like you’re feeling stuck and overwhelmed, and you're not sure where to turn next. Your desire to feel more secure about work and find a way to quiet those thoughts shows how much you want things to change. Even though it feels like you’ve tried everything, it’s clear that you’re open to exploring options that might bring you some relief. Would you be interested in reflecting on anything, like your sleep or stress patterns, to try to understand what’s been contributing to these restless nights?

It sounds like you're feeling overwhelmed and unsure of what steps might help at this point—you're carrying a lot on your shoulders. It's not easy to face all this. Maybe we can start small by exploring what specific thoughts or fears come up the most at night? That might help us identify manageable steps forward.

Thank you for sharing that. Talking through those recurring thoughts or fears is a great idea—it could shine a light on patterns behind your stress and help ease some of the pressure. What do you find yourself thinking about most often when those worst-case scenarios take over? Are there particular concerns that stand out?

I think about the possibility of getting laid off a lot. With the way the economy is going, I feel like I’d be one of the first to go, and then how would I pay the bills or take care of my family? That fear just keeps looping in my head.

That fear of losing your job and the uncertainty about how you'd provide for your family sounds incredibly heavy to carry, especially if it feels like it's always looming. It's understandable that this has been consuming so much of your energy and making it hard to find peace at night. How do you think this fear is affecting your day-to-day life or the way you approach work?

I definitely feel more on edge during the day. At work, I’m constantly overthinking everything I do, trying to make sure I don’t make mistakes or give anyone a reason to fire me. It’s exhausting, and I think it’s making me less productive because I get so caught up in my anxiety.

That sounds incredibly draining—not only are you working hard to avoid mistakes, but the anxiety about job security is affecting your focus and energy. It's like this constant effort to protect what you have is actually taking more out of you. What do you think would help you feel a little more grounded or less pressured during the day?

I'm not really sure what would help. Maybe if there was a way to feel more confident in my work or more secure in my position, but I don't know how to get there. Right now, it’s hard to see past all the worry.

It’s clear that feeling more confident and secure in your job is really important to you, though it feels tough to imagine how to get there with all that worry taking over. It can be hard to focus on confidence when the stress is so intense. If you'd like, we could explore small steps or approaches that could help you reclaim some calm—or even just some control—over your experience during the workday or at night. Would you like to talk about potential ways to start that process?

It’s clear that feeling more confident and secure in your job is really important to you, though it feels tough to imagine how to get there with all that worry taking over. It can be hard to focus on confidence when the stress is so intense. If you'd like, we could explore small steps or approaches that could help you reclaim some calm—or even just some control—over your experience during the workday or at night. Would you like to talk about potential ways to start that process?

It sounds like you're open to the idea of finding ways to ease the stress and feel a bit more in control, even though it’s hard to imagine right now. Taking small steps could help lighten the load and make things feel more manageable. Before we go into that, is there anything else you’d like to share about how this is impacting you or what you hope to gain from this conversation?

I guess I just want to stop feeling so stuck—like everything depends on me but I can't get it right. I want to be able to sleep, focus at work, and stop worrying all the time. I want to feel like I'm doing enough for my family and not failing them.

It takes a lot of courage to share those feelings, and the fact that you’re here shows how much you care about doing the best for your family and yourself. Feeling stuck, exhausted, and worried must make it so hard to see the positives in the effort you're putting in. But you're showing dedication and a drive to make things better, and that's important. Would it be helpful if we talked about small steps that can help you work toward feeling more rested, less worried, or even just more in control of your stress?
